ThisdocumentmustonlybegeneratedineOps. 26072021150549693097 Generated Date: 18-Aug-2021 13:49:02 PM

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) has requested the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) for a knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) to advance 
research and develop policy advice on ways to advance the equitable provision of public services 
and social security transfers in the context of wider fiscal modernization requirements. Specifically, 
these areas cover (i) the degree of alignment between the PRC’s current tax structure and the 
country’s expenditure needs under the high-quality growth model; (ii) the extent to which current 
intergovernmental fiscal arrangements ensure a sufficient and equitable allocation of resources 
across the different tiers of government, relative to assigned service delivery responsibilities; and 
(iii) inefficiencies in current public financial management systems and processes. Finally, the 
research will be used to provide evidence-based policy advice on ways to introduce improvements 
in the analyzed areas. 
 
2.  The  support  will  be  delivered  through  a  combination  of  analytical  work,  policy 
recommendations, and capacity development activities, including workshops, seminars, and the 
study of relevant international experiences in the two reform areas. The TA is included in the 
indicative 2021 PRC nonlending program and will be included in the Indicative Country Pipeline 
and Monitoring report proposed for approval in Q3 2021.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  The coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic has had a huge impact on the global 
economy, including in the PRC. With a 6.8% contraction in gross domestic product (GDP) during 
the first quarter of 2020, the PRC recorded its first negative quarterly growth since 1992, far 
exceeding the impact of the 2008 international financial crisis.2 Driven by the countercyclical 
expenditure framework that was implemented in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, the PRC 
recorded a CNY3.76 trillion fiscal deficit—equivalent to 3.7% of GDP over 2020. Of that deficit, 
CNY2.78 trillion is accounted for by the central government and CNY0.98 trillion by subnational 
governments. 
 
4.  With the improvements in pandemic control and the resulting resumption of social and 
economic activities, the country’s economy has improved significantly after entering the second 
quarter of 2020, and the growth rate of GDP reached 3.2%.3 Notwithstanding this gradual 
recovery of economic activities, the PRC is still facing serious and structural fiscal management 
challenges that hamper the full realization of the high-quality growth agenda, and in particular the 
effective, equitable, and efficient provision of public services and social security transfers.4 
 
5.  The existing fiscal management challenges can be broadly categorized into four areas: (i) 
a growing gap in the growth of government revenues and government expenditures (figure); (ii) a 
current tax structure, dominated by indirect taxes, which does not generate the required levels of 
revenue; (iii) structural vertical and horizontal imbalances in the allocation of resources (and thus, 
the inequitable provision of services and social security transfers); and (iv) the fragmented 
 
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 8 July 2021. 
2  O. Williams-Grut. 2020. China’s economy shrinks for the first time since records began after coronavirus outbreak. 
Yahoo Finance. 17 April. 
3  Z. Lanxi. 2020. NBS: China’s GDP grows 4.9% in Q3. China Daily. 19 October. 
4 The  high-quality  growth  agenda  seeks  a  rebalancing  of  the  traditional  investment-led  growth  paradigm,  by 
emphasizing the imperative of a greener and more equitable growth model, driven by consumption and productivity.

2 
organization and administration of public financial management, coupled with capacity constraints 
at the subnational level.5 
 
6.  In expenditure responsibilities, the PRC is one of the most decentralized countries in the 
world (subnational governments provide roughly 85% of all public services). As a result, the 
combined impact of these four challenges on both the quantity and quality of public services 
delivered by subnational governments has been substantial and negative. 
Trends in Government Expenditure and Revenues 
(CNY million) 
 
Note: Over 2010–2018, the fiscal deficit of the People’s Republic of China increased from –0.36% of GDP to –4.66% of 
gross domestic product. Statista. China: Budget Balance in Relation to Gross Domestic Product (GDP) from 2009 to 2019 
with Forecasts until 2026.  
Source: China Academy of Social Sciences (Center for Public Policy Research, 2020). 
 
 
7.  The research on these identified constraints has previously focused on analyzing the 
individual constraints separately, instead of in relation to each other. The research has also lacked 
empirical evidence, especially from the subnational level. These have resulted in a prevalence of 
piecemeal policy advice. 
 
8.  The TA is aligned with ADB’s following operational priorities: (i) addressing remaining 
poverty  and  reducing  inequalities,  (ii)  accelerating  progress  in  gender  equity,  and  (iii) 
strengthening governance and institutional capacity. The TA is also aligned with the current 
country partnership strategy’s objective of strengthening institutions and their capacity to support 
reforms.6 Finally,  the  TA  is  aligned  with  the  Sustainable  Development  Goals  10  (reduced 
inequalities) and 16 (peace and strong institutions). 
 
 
5 Vertical fiscal imbalances refer to the mismatch between spending responsibilities that are assigned to lower levels 
of government and the financial resources available to those local governments. Horizontal fiscal imbalances refer 
to fiscal disparities within the same tier of government; horizontal imbalances thus are an equalization concern. The 
PRC’s public financial management system, across the different tiers of government, comprises four separate 
budgets,  each  with  their own  financial  reporting  and  accounting  practices: the  General  Public  Budget,  the 
Government Fund Budget, the Social Security Budget, and the State-Owned Enterprises Budget.  
6 ADB. 2021. People’s Republic of China, 2021–2025–Toward High-Quality, Green Development. Manila.

3 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: equitable provision of public services and 
social  security  support  achieved.7 The  TA  will  have  the  following  outcome:  policies  for 
modernizing the fiscal underpinning of public services and social security improved. 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
10.  Through the TA, support will be provided to assess the critical institutional constraints 
identified by the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences in a comprehensive and empirical manner, 
and to provide policy recommendations on how to address them. Implementation of the TA will 
result in three outputs: 
 
11.  Output 1: Government’s understanding of selected international experiences with 
the organization and financing of public service delivery and social security systems 
enhanced. Activities under this output will include preparing comparative research (desk study) 
on international experiences with organizing and financing public service delivery and social 
security systems. It will also include the delivery of capacity development workshops. 
 
12.  Output  2:  Government’s  understanding  of  the  empirical  relation  between  tax 
structure, intergovernmental fiscal framework, public financial management systems and 
processes, and the delivery of services and social security enhanced. This output will be 
achieved through a combination of an in-depth empirical assessment, including field work in 
several local governments, and capacity development workshops. 
 
13.  Output 3: Policy advice on the reform of the PRC’s tax structure, intergovernmental 
fiscal framework, and public financial management practices finalized. This output will be 
achieved through the preparation of a report synthesizing the findings and conclusions from 
outputs 1 and 2, including evidence-based policy recommendations. 
 
14.  Given the nature of the government’s request, TA is seen as the most appropriate 
approach. At this stage, it is not foreseen that high-level technology solutions will be used in the 
implementation of the TA; the TA will be administered by ADB. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $350,000, of which $300,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund. The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 
2. 
 
16.  The executing agency will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, 
office, office supplies, secretarial assistance, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
 
7 Government of the PRC. 2021. The Outline of the Fourteenth Five-Year Plan for National Economic and Social 
Development and the Long-range Objectives through the Year 2035. Beijing.

4 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  ADB will administer the TA. The East Asia Department’s Public Management, Financial 
Sector and Regional Cooperation and Integration Division will administer the TA. ADB will engage 
consultants and carry out procurement following ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended 
from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions. 
The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table. 
 
Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative implementation  August 2021–December 2024 
period

ADB = Asian Development Bank, IC = international consultant, NC = national consultant, TA = technical assistance. 
a The Chinese Academy of Social Sciences is the premier comprehensive national academic research organization in 
the People’s Republic of China in the fields of philosophy and social sciences, with the obligation of advancing and 
innovating in the scientific research of philosophy, social sciences, and policies. It is directly affiliated with the State 
Council. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
18.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or 
staff instructions.8 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of the People’s Republic of China for Supporting the Fiscal Sustainability of Public 
Services and Social Security, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
 
8  Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).
